Authors:
Jadson José Souza de Oliveira, Jean-Marc Moncalvo, Simona
Margaritescu, Marina Capelari
Title:
A morphological and phylogenetic evaluation of Marasmius
sect. Globulares (GlobularesSicci complex) with nine new taxa from the
Neotropical Atlantic Forest
Journal: Persoonia: Molecular Phylogeny and Evolution of Fungi
Keywords:
Agaricales; Marasmiaceae; Neotropics; phylogenetics;
systematics; stirpes; taxonomy.
Abstract:
The largest and most recently emended Marasmius sect.
Globulares (GlobularesSicci complex) has increased in number of species
annually while its infrasectional organization remains inconclusive.
During forays in remnants of the Atlantic Rainforest in Brazil, 25 taxa
of Marasmius belonging to sect. Globulares were collected from which
nine are herein proposed as new: Marasmius altoribeirensis, M. hobbitii,
M. linderioides var. ambicellularis, M. luteoolivaceus, M.
neotropicalis, M. pallidobrunneus, M. pseudoniveoaffinis, M.
rhabarbarinoides and M. venatifolius. We took this opportunity to
evaluate sect. Globulares sensu Antonín & Noorderloos in particular,
combining morphological examination and both single and multilocus
phylogenetic analyses using LSU and ITS data, including Neotropical
samples to a broader and more globally distributed sampling of over 200
strains. Three different approaches were developed in order to make a
better use of the informativeness of the markers in Bayesian and Maximum
Likelihood analyses. The implementation of theses approaches resulted
in: i) the observation the phylogenetic placement of the new and known
taxa herein studied among the other taxa of a wide sampling of the
section; ii) the reconstruction of improved phylogenetic trees
presenting more strongly supported resolution especially from
intermediary to deep nodes; iii) more clear evidences of non-monophyly
for the series in sect. Sicci and sect. Globulares sensu Singer by this
more stringent evaluation; and iv) the existence of several monophyletic
suprespecific groups equivalent to the stirpes of Singer  clusters of
morphologically close species. These two latter results corroborate with
the findings in previous studies with whole genus analyses. Based on the
results, we proposed a new infrasectional classification elevating the
Singers concept of stirpes up to series. The result was fourteen new
series and the emendation of two extent ones and three subsections
gathering these series were also proposed based on major clades.
